Award.AwardTitle: Hydrogen Bonding, Proton Transfer, and Clusters on the Brink of Chemical Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms A Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kenneth R. Leopold at the University of Minnesota performs fundamental studies on the forces of attraction between molecules. These forces are ubiquitous in nature and their study underlies our understanding a wide variety of chemical phenomena. The work is done by creating small clusters of two or three molecules and studying their physical properties. By grouping only a few molecules at a time, the simplification needed to fully understand the attractive forces is achieved. This work identifies prototypical systems that provide the most useful basic information. Whenever possible, prototypes are chosen that contain molecules known or suspected of being active in the Earth's atmosphere, thus providing foundational knowledge for atmospheric science. The direct focus on atmospherically important problems produces basic information needed to rationally evaluate the impact of both natural and anthropogenic changes to the environment. Additional impact is realized in the education of students and postdoctoral fellows who work on these problems. This project continues to grow a broader set of collaborators at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). The ability to collect a data in a short time is conducive to allowing undergraduate students the opportunity to see a project through from beginning to end.

Microwave spectroscopy in a supersonic jet is used to determine molecular and electronic structure in small weakly bound complexes. Studies include complexes containing sulfur trioxide, carboxylic acids, sulfuric acid, and/or amines. Special emphasis is placed on systems that are on the brink of chemical reaction. Proton transfer, for example, is one common theme and its study provides a glimpse of the role of solvation in promoting chemical change. Quantum mechanical tunneling, when observed, offers experimental benchmarks with which to challenge theoretical chemical dynamics. Three-dimentional printing is explored as a convenient and inexpensive means of optimizing the design of the supersonic nozzles used to generate the chemical species of interest. The broader impact of this work lies, in part, in its elucidation of the fundamental interactions that govern solvation and determine the properties of matter. The understanding obtained informs fields as diverse as molecular biology and environmental science. Additional impact is derived from the training of graduate, undergraduate, and postdoctoral students that it provides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kenneth R. Leopold and his students at the University of Minnesota have used state-of-the-art instrumentation to study how molecules aggregate. This is done with the aim of understanding the fundamental factors that influence the outcome of chemical reactions.

 

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this work lies in its detailed elucidation of the interaction between molecules. The work brings together pairs of molecules in an isolated (gas phase) environment and studies the details of their preferred relative orientation and the degree to which they vibrate in each other?s proximity. Then, by adding one molecule at a time, the effects of multiple interactions can be assessed. This approach can be viewed as building bulk phase matter one molecule at a time, thereby developing an understanding of how the microscopic properties of matter evolve into the properties of macroscopic samples.

 

The work was accomplished by recording how the systems studied absorb microwaves. The specific set of microwave frequencies that a molecule or cluster absorbs contains accurate information about its structure and about the manner in which atoms are bonded together. Our work has established the existence and explored the properties of a new class of compounds called ?carboxylic sulfuric anhydrides?. It has also led to new insights on reactions involving hydrolysis (reaction with water) and proton transfer. These latter processes are ubiquitous in nature and this work has provided a unique perspective at a molecular level. The formation of the carboxylic sulfuric anhydrides represents a new type of process discovered in this laboratory. Another aspect of the intellectual merit of the project has been the creation of a program (?DAPPERS?) which greatly aids in the handling and analysis of the kind of data obtained in this work. The program has been made available for free download by other groups that study microwave absorption by molecules.

 

Broader Impact

A significant aspect of the broader impact of this work lies in its educational component. Students engaged in this research obtained valuable experience in advanced experimental methods and in the rigorous handling of highly accurate experimental data. Students who have worked on this project have gone on to work in areas such as safety compliance and in the creation of scripts for educational science videos. Two additional Ph.D.s are currently in the pipeline and several undergraduates have received their first exposure to scientific research working on projects supported by this grant. Also, because the work addresses fundamental aspects of intermolecular interactions, it can broadly impact many areas. For example, the carboxylic sulfuric anhydrides noted above are of potential importance in the formation of atmospheric aerosol, whose formation impacts climate and the global energy budget. In the course of this work, these species have been characterized, and preliminary estimates of their concentrations in various regions of the atmosphere have been made. These studies thus provide basic information needed to rationally evaluate the impact of both natural and anthropogenic perturbations to the environment. This aspect of the work is best described as foundational science upon which atmospheric chemists can draw. Beyond the potential impact on atmospheric science, however, connections to biology are easy to discern in view of the role of proton transfer in biological systems.
